Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from Alex just as I was about to dial my next sales call. “Did you forget we were supposed to have dinner with my parents this Saturday?” The words stung—I had, in fact, scheduled an extra shift to keep up my momentum at work. As a girlfriend, I knew I should call him, talk it out, and smooth over the misunderstanding before it grew into something bigger. But as a telemarketer, I was on a roll; my sales numbers were soaring, and my manager had just sent a congratulatory email, urging me to keep up the pace. I stared at my phone, torn. If I paused now to call Alex, I’d lose my rhythm and maybe a few sales. If I waited, the tension between us might fester. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—be the attentive partner, or the top performer. The phone in my hand felt heavier with every passing second.
